passages.text: August 31, 2025 06:00 AM GMT

Last week, our US economics team adjusted its Fed forecast. Until Chair Powell's speech at Jackson Hole, we saw the Fed's reaction function overweighting the risks from above- target and now rising inflation. After all, inflation has stayed above \(2\%\) for more than four years, and even though nonfarm payrolls and underlying aggregate demand have clearly slowed, the unemployment rate remains roughly unchanged from a year earlier at \(4.2\%\) . The economy is essentially operating at the Fed's estimate of full employment.

But as John Maynard Keynes said, "When the facts change, I change my mind." The economy has evolved close to our expectations: tariff- driven inflation is emerging after a lag with a slowdown in hiring but little trace of labor market slack. However, in his speech, Powell appeared to spell out a change in the Fed's reaction function. It now leans toward managing the risk of a bigger slowdown and is more willing to live with the threat of higher inflation.

Ultimately, though, our baseline policy forecast has only changed modestly, and in many respects has already been priced into markets. We now see a rate cut in September, consistent with futures quotes, and we look for a quarterly pace of 25bp cuts through the end of next year. We expect a slightly lower policy rate than the nearly \(3\%\) implied by markets, but the difference is minimal.

Against the backdrop of only modest forecast changes and views that align well with market pricing, our central cases for most asset classes remain largely unchanged. In sum, we see mostly positive returns across fixed income and equities into year- end. For instance, in US Treasuries, based on a forecast of a slowing economy and falling policy rates, our colleagues still see yields falling. And they still expect curve steepening, especially with the Fed's increased comfort in cutting rates despite inflationary pressures. We continue to expect a weaker US dollar because we see more policy rate- gasing from the Fed than from other central banks, among other factors. While the Fed lowered the bar for rate cuts, the ECB seems to have raised it.
But manifold uncertainties lie ahead, and baselines tell only part of the story.

Although we've built in a slight change in the Powell Fed's reaction function, we will have to see how it might evolve with turnover among Fed policymakers, especially when Chair Powell's term is up. Given the public calls for lower rates, a natural question is whether new leadership will push the reaction function even further toward accepting higher inflation, all else equal.

That uncertainty underscores how dynamic the market environment could become. A growing recognition of increased inflation tolerance from the Fed could be a catalyst for markets. In terms of our core views, these risks amplify the potential for USD weakness. Moreover, a pronounced shift in the policy reaction function could help drive a twist steepener in the Treasury curve, a change from our base case of a
MORGAN STANLEY & CO.LLC
Chief Global Economist
Michael D Zezas, CFA

straight bull steepener.

straight bull steepener.Those developments would likely not alter our view of continued, if plodding, economic growth, so our comfort with corporate credit, whose aggregate financing needs are more closely tied to shorter maturities, would remain more or less intact. But our US equity strategy team cites a long- end bond sell- off as a key risk to the current rally, similar to the early April dynamic. In our dialogue with clients, many argue that if such risks materialize, a policy response would be likely, and we agree. Our rates strategy colleagues in particular have highlighted the scope the Treasury has already acknowledged to adjust issuance patterns in response to market pricing. But from a trading perspective, we think it's important to keep in mind that these moves are likely to be reactive, not proactive. In any event, we need to get through the summer before we can turn our attention to what may be a lively autumn.Enjoy your Sunday.Send Us Feedback
US Economics Weekly: The Fed shifts to risk management cuts
Federal Reserve Monitor: We now forecast Fed rate cuts beginning in September
Federal Reserve Monitor: A dovish Jackson Hole
Global Macro Strategist: At the Edge of Hot Summer, At the Threshold of a Larger Fall

US Factory Surveys: The S&P manufacturing PMI jumped to 53.3 in the preliminary reading for August. We expect the ISM measure to rise 1.0 point to 49.0, to a level very close to the average so far this year. Over the same period, manufacturing output has risen by an average of \(0.2\%\) per month.

US Construction Spending: We expect that single- family homebuilding again weighed on construction, pulling it to a \(0.2\%\) decline. The report also shows net declines in business structures spending so far this year, which we expect continue into 3Q, notwithstanding growth in Al- related powerplant investment and data centers.
EurgArea HiCP: We expect HiCP inflation to edge up slightly to \(2.1\% Y\) in August, from \(2.0\% Y\) in July, with core down slightly to \(2.2\% Y\) from \(2.3\% Y\)
Brazil 2Q GDP: We expect 2Q GDP to rise \(0.5\% Q\) SA and \(2.3\% Y\) , driven by a mild deceleration in private consumption, still sustained by a strong labor market.

Poland NBP Rate Decision: With slowing inflation and wage growth, we continue to expect the NBP to lower its key policy rate to \(4.75\%\) . Still, uncertainty related to regulated prices and potential tax hikes creates risks
for more cautious forward guidance and an eventual pause in the cycle until early 2026.

US Motor Vehicle Sales: We expect some slight slowing, from a 16.4 million unit annual rate in July to a 16.0 million unit pace in August. Some demand is probably being pulled forward by the expiration of EV tax credits at the end of September.

US Job Openings (JOLTs): Private sector job openings, hiring and layoff rates all slipped slightly last month but were unchanged from a year earlier. Notwithstanding the slowing in payrolls, they have not indicated increased slack. Maybe with this report for July, they will - it was the July employment report that showed a sharp downward revision to 2Q.

US Beige Book: The Beige Book has not been a particularly useful indicator of activity in recent years, consistently suggesting weaker growth than occurred. Still, any hint it offers on firm behavior around tariffs could be useful.

US Productivity and Costs: We estimate that 2Q productivity is revised up to \(3.2\% \mathrm{Q}\) SAAR from \(2.4\% \mathrm{Q}\) SAAR following an upward revision to 2Q GDP and some downward revision to 2Q labor input. Unit labor cost is trimmed similarly, to \(0.9\%\) from \(1.6\%\) . Both follow much less favorable readings in 1Q: In 1Q, GDP and productivity looked much weaker because of the flood of imports; in 2Q, both swung upwards as imports reversed.

US Jobless Claims: Jobless claims remain low. Continuing claims rose in May and June but appear to have stabilized since then. The pattern in the two is consistent with no- faster layoffs but a slightly slower hiring rate.
Euro Area Retail Sales: We expect July retail sales to decline by \(0.5\% \mathrm{M}\) in July, after \(+0.3\% \mathrm{M}\) in June.

US Employment Situation: Our forecasts of a 70k rise in payrolls and 80k rise in private payrolls are very similar to July payrolls: a slowing from earlier in the year, but not the sharp deceleration that June and May now show. The unemployment rate last month was \(4.2\%\) but right on the cusp of \(4.3\%\) . We think it sticks at \(4.2\%\) : breakevens have been falling; and we expect some further downward pressure on participation rates. Average hourly earnings rise on trend, and we expect no change in the workweek.
Japan Monthly Labor Survey: We expect total cash earnings to increase by \(3.0\% \mathrm{Y}\) in July.
Japan Family Income and Expenditure Survey: We forecast real household consumption expenditure to increase by \(2.3\% \mathrm{Y}\) in July.
Germany Manufacturing Orders: We expect manufacturing orders to decline further in July (- \(0.4\% \mathrm{M}\) after - \(1.0\% \mathrm{M}\) in June).

Morgan Stanley uses a relative rating system using terms such as Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated or Underweight (see definitions below). Morgan Stanley does not assign ratings of Buy, Hold or Sell to the stocks we cover. Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated and Underweight are not the equivalent of buy, hold and sell. Investors should carefully read the definitions of all ratings used in Morgan Stanley Research. In addition, since Morgan Stanley Research contains more complete information concerning the analyst's views, investors should carefully read Morgan Stanley Research, in its entirety, and not infer the contents from the rating alone. In any case, ratings (or research) should not be used or relied upon as investment advice. An investor's decision to buy or sell a stock should depend on individual circumstances (such as the investor's existing holdings) and other considerations.
(as of July 31, 2025)

The Stock Ratings described below apply to Morgan Stanley's Fundamental Equity Research and do not apply to Debt Research produced by the Firm. For disclosure purposes only (in accordance with FINRA requirements), we include the category headings of Buy, Hold, and Sell alongside our ratings of Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated and Underweight. Morgan Stanley does not assign ratings of Buy, Hold or Sell to the stocks we cover. Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated and Underweight are not the equivalent of buy, hold, and sell but represent recommended relative weightings (see definitions below). To satisfy regulatory requirements, we correspond Overweight, our most positive stock rating, with a buy recommendation; we correspond Equal- weight and Not- Rated to hold and Underweight to sell recommendations, respectively.

Data include common stock and ADRs currently assigned ratings. Investment Banking Clients are companies from whom Morgan Stanley received investment banking compensation in the last 12 months. Due to rounding off of decimals, the percentages provided in the % of total' column may not add up to exactly 100 percent.

Overweight (O or Over) - The stock's total return is expected to exceed the total return of the relevant country MSCI Index or the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis over the next 12-18 months.

Equal-weight (E or Equal) - The stock's total return is expected to be in line with the total return of the relevant country MSCI Index or the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis over the next 12-18 months.

Not-Rated (NR) - Currently the analyst does not have adequate conviction about the stock's total return relative to the relevant country MSCI Index or the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Underweight (U or Under) - The stock's total return is expected to be below the total return of the relevant country MSCI Index or the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.
Unless otherwise specified, the time frame for price targets included in Morgan Stanley Research is 12 to 18 months.
Attractive (A): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months to be attractive vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.

In-Line (I): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months to be in line with the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.Cautious (C): The analyst views the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months with caution vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.

Benchmarks for each region are as follows: North America - S&P 500; Latin America - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI Latin America Index; Europe - MSCI Europe; Japan - TOPIX; Asia - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI sub-regional index or MSCI AC Asia Pacific ex Japan Index.
